Posts.Content: On 9/13/2007 never4get wrote: My mother was just diagnosed this week with stg 2b (at least we wont know definatley until after surgery).  She found a lump in her R armpit and it is ductal carcinoma; she is 52yrs old and the picture of health/active.  After having a positive biopsy of this mass she found they were going to wait 2 week to do the breast MRI and PETS scan; incidentally this cancer is not showing up on mammogram- even yesterday it did not show up on mammogram although the radiologist and we know it is there from the PETS and MRI- anyway I was pushy and got all her diagnostic testing pushed up to the beginning of this week; and now we have already seen an oncologist and are going to start to schedule for surgery 2 weeks before they would have even had her testing done! Bottom line- I wouldn't wait for or trust in MD's to automatically schedule you for your PETS scan and f'/u MRI's- be proactive, ask questions and don't sit and wait for anything.  I wish you all the luck in the world and will keep you in my daily prayers!! I was wondering how you were diagnosed, how did you find your breast CA and what type is it?? We are looking for some positive feedback.  Also -did you use the local oncologist/surgeon or did you go to Cancer Centers of America or somewhere like that?? We are in the early stages of this and I have all the hope in the world.  Thanks for your time and I'll keep you in my prayers. I found my cancer when I was scratching my breast.  I had a 2cm tumor very defined.  Easy to grab.  Mammogram missed it 6 months before.  At 48 I had gotten lazy on self examines.  I had lumpectomy and 2 lymp nodes removed.  4 rounds of chemo, and 61/2 weeks of radiation and I take tamoxifin because my cancer was estrogen +.  That was 2 years and 3 months ago since my last radiation treatment.    So far So good. Kimarie
Posts.Title: Stage 2 Breast Cancer!!

Posts.Content: Hi, Stage 2 Breast Cancer, after I had surgery, chemo and radiation.  I started taking tamoxifin.  You will have pet scans, bone scans, mamograms, ultrasounds.  They will keep a close eye on your body to make sure your cancer stays gone.  Good luck.  I will say that I ended up with a frozen shoulder about 6 months after radiation.  Had to go through steroid shot and a lot of physical therapy.  Watch your shoulders, exercise and take good care of yourself.  Kimarie
Posts.Title: Stage 2 Breast Cancer!!

Posts.Content: On 8/29/2007 CONNEANN wrote: Thanks so much for responding. Its always good to hear from others who have gone through the same. Did you ask for the scans or it is an automatic?? I will be seeing my oncologist in a couple of weeks. I finished radiation yesterday. yeh!!!!!!!!!. Connie   Hey Connie,  I think it is standard for your Doctor too order these scans.  Not sure how often.  I have been scanned twice for everything since my last radiation treatment.  So once a year unless you find another lump. Kimarie
Posts.Title: Stage 2 Breast Cancer!!

Posts.Content: On 9/9/2007 gilpatsgirl wrote: I have tried tamoxifen and arimidex for post chemo & radiation treatment for stage 1 ibc. The arimidex made me so tired, depressed and horrible joint pain. I'm supposed to try aromisin next but I can't get myself to start taking it. I've read they don't know the long term effects of these drugs. Anyone else dealing with this? The chemo was horrible but I'd say these drugs are worse. Hi Gilpatsgirl, I was treated same with stage 2 bc lymp node involved.  I agree that the femara may have caused me bad joint pain and depression.  I switched back to tamoxifen and I do feel better.  I could not bring myself to take arimidex.  Scares the hell out of me.  I think we just need to focus on each day feeling the best we can.  None of us know whats going to happen tomorrow.  Good luck and God Bless us All Kimarie
Posts.Title: Aromatase inhibitors

Posts.Content: On 9/2/2007 Kittycath wrote: I hope one of the health care folks on this site will respond to the question of whether or not black kohosh is safe for estrogen receptive/tamolifen--please answer docs or nurse!  I too would like to try this IF it is safe. I googled info on Black Cohosh,  It said that they do not recommend if you had estrogen receptive breast cancer.  Not enough study to know if you can be harmed by it.  I went this weekend and bought a bottle of the black cohosh, took two tablets before I came across this information.  I have a doctors appointment, I will ask them. Kimarie
Posts.Title: Black Cohosh

Posts.Content: Is it ok to take Black Cohosh is you are estrogen receptive.  I take tamoxifin to keep my hormones from producing estrogen.  I think thats how it works.  confused Kimarie
Posts.Title: Black Cohosh

Posts.Content: Dear Anna,  I too had same treatment for estrogen positive breast cancer.  I am on my second year of tamoxifin.  I could not take the side effects of femara or arimidex.  I think it is very normal to worry about it coming back.  I got up with a swollen throat this morning, I have already wondered if cancer came back in throat.  Then I just give thanks for today.  I wish we did not worry about reoccurrence but dont know how to get that out of my head.  I am 48.  Good luck.  Kimarie
Posts.Title: Recurrance

Posts.Content: On 3/18/2007 Nativemainer wrote: I'm not afraid of the lumpectomy, I'm afraid of the process when they inject dye and radioactive whatever--apparently that is done several hours before surgery with no sedation or anethsesia--"like a needle localization" was what I was told, and the localization was like haveing a red hot poker jabbed into my breast and then hooked up to an electrical shocker that went off everycouple of seconds until the surgeon took it out.  I don't think I can handle that for hours (they said it take up to 4 hours for the dye to get to the nodes).  I had to be medicated just to get through the hour between the localization and the biopsy, and they say they will not medicate me for this--"no one else has ever needed medication".  Of course, no one else ever needed medication for the localization, either, but I did.  I'm almost ready to write off treatment althogether.  I'm not afraid of dying, I'm terrifed of going through the procedures.  What happens if I have a complete panic attack?  Or a heart attack from the fear and anxiety?   Dear Native Mainer,  I was 46 and terrifed like you when I had the same thing done.  I took a valium before the procedure, but I cried so hard the doctor kept talking to me while he was injecting the dye.  I promise I really didnt feel much.  Just was a basket case through out the procedure.  Afterwards they took me too surgery, for lumpectomy, went home same day.  The needle biopsy, in the surgeons office was the worst part of having cancer.  You are right about it feeling like red hot poker.  Some ladies get lucky and it doesnt hurt them.  You have 50 50 chance of them hitting a nerve.  Which it sounds like happen to you and me. Good luck, Kimarie
Posts.Title: Coping with fear and anxiety

Posts.Content: On 3/12/2007 Kris6332 wrote: I have heard that breastfeeding lowers your chance of getting breast cancer.   Has anyone else ever heard that?  My mom died 2 years ago from colon cancer, but I also have several aunts who are currently fighting breast cancer.  I'm 31 and mother to three, an 11year old son, an 8 year old daughter, and a 15 month old daughter.  I breastfed all for at least a year or longer.  Sure would be nice to think that what I heard about it lowering breast cancer risk was true.  Thanks, Kristy E. Dear Kristy, I breast fed my son for 6 weeks and my daughter for 3 months. 22 years later I got breast cancer.  Am two years since diagnosis.  Had lumpectomy, chemo, radiation and tamoifin.  Doing well now, am clear for now.  Kimarie
Posts.Title: breastfeeding

Posts.Content: On 8/13/2007 Bleudog wrote: I was told by another survivor that I could take Cymbalta and Zoloft and it would cause me no trouble.  Replies will be appreciated. Hi Bleudog,  My oncologist explained to me that by taking any kind of antidepressant it counter acted against the tomaxifin that I take.  I do have depression on and off, and I am very angry sometimes.  But I try to talk myself into feeling sorry for people I hear about, and how much worse off they are.  I believe the medication for estrogen positive cancer does have some side effects.  Memory, depression, hot flashed and sleepless nights.  I take advil pm at night so I sleep through most hot flashes.  Good luck.      Kimarie
Posts.Title: Medicines

Posts.Content: On 11/24/2007 Just Sassy wrote: Hi--I am a 7 year breast cancer survivor (and happy about it:). It was and estrogen receptive tumor(s) and so of course, they shut me down so to speak. Rather suddenly, I might add. So I had the hot flashes ad nauseum etc. Also, I have had quite a bit of weight gain which had never been much of an issue until all this Adventure. I have not been able to find much literature on this aspect (nor much that has been helpful in terms of losing it) as their whole focus is to save your life. Has anyone else had this issue? And has anyone found any better reasons or specific help other than the usual 'just eat right and exercise?' thanks~ JS  Hey JS,  I am just finishing my second year of tamoxifin.  I had lumpectomy, chemo and radiation.  I am 48yrs.  I have gained atleast 20lbs this last year.  I believe chemo induced menapause and tamoxifin might be the culpret.  Hoping so.  I eat right and walk or jog 10 miles plus a week.  My hips and feet are achey. If I dont watch every calorie during the week, I continue to gain.  Have stopped gaining for 4 months.  Never had belly fat before, it is very uncomfortable.  God Bless us.  Kimarie
Posts.Title: weight loss after treatment

Posts.Content: On 1/16/2007 Brattyblueeyez wrote: I found a lump in my left breast in October and went straight to the doctor since it runs in my family. He ordered a mammogram and ultrasound, I had that done at the beginning of Dec and then was sent to a surgeon because one of my lumps ( I have several in my left breast) had a shadow and was fairly good size.  I have a biopsy done last Friday and am very bruised and sore. Even under my arm is sore. The surgeon called me yesterday afternoon late and said that the lump he removed came back benign but things aren't lining up with what he saw on the mammo's and ultrasound. He now wants to do a lumpectomy after another mamogram and ultrasound next week. He said he was fully thinking the lump he biopsied was going to come back as carsinoma. The lump he biopsed wasn't the one that my ob/gyn was concerned about. He told me not to worry , to let him worry. But as I look online about stuff for lumpectomys it says that it is usually followed by 6 weeks of radiation.  Can anyone offer some advice , been thru this or know someone that's been thru this same thing?   Thanks!! Hello, I had a biopsy on a lump, My surgeon really thought it was scar tissue.  So when the cancer result came back we were very surprised.  I had a lumpectomy and a couple of lymp nodes removed.  It had spread to one lymp node.  4 rounds of chemo and radiation 6 1/2 weeks of.  The surgery went very well, not much pain at all.  Healed well also.  Good luck.   Kimarie
Posts.Title: new here with a question about lumpectomy's

Posts.Content: Hi, I too had same problems, joints, stiffness, depression. Went back to taking tamoxifin, not nearly the side effects that other drugs have.  Kimarie
Posts.Title: aromasin/arimidex side effects

Posts.Content: On 12/22/2007 Goodattitude wrote: Well, I went to the doctors again.  My oncologist switched me to Tamoxifen.  The depressed feelings have not gone away yet, but to boot I woke up this morning at 330A, with the dry heaves for a few hours.  I'm really discouraged about these ill feelings.  All I seem to want to do is lay on the couch.  I've made the decision to stop the Tamoxifen and the Zocor because what I've read about the side effects, both of these can cause depression and nauseau.  I've been through Chemo and radiation.  It's time for me to feel good for a change and I want to take charge of my own body and not be chemically altered all the time. Thanks for the support and the advice.        Hey Good attitude, I did the tamoxifin for a year, couple months on the femara, then switched back to tamoxifin.  My Doctors said that if I did not take some kind of estrogen blocker than my chemo was for nothing.   They work hand in hand to keep cancer from coming back.  God Bless us All.  I too suffer from depression.  I started hurting myself, to displace the pain I felt emotionally.  I now take xanax when I get like that.  It helps alot.  I can cut them in half, stops the full blown depression or anger or crying jags.  Dont have to take them but about every 6 weeks. Hang in there, Kimarie
Posts.Title: Side Effects - Arimidex

Posts.Content: Hey Lisa2,  I was 46 when I was chemo induced menapause.  My Doctor had me take tamoxifin the first year and then ask me to take femara.  I had too many side effects, so I went back to tamoxifin.  The weight gain is the worst side effect for me.  It may not be the best treatment but it is the best I can do for now.  Good luck Kimare
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen or Fareston?

Posts.Content: I have been on Tamoxifin for 2 years, also have noticed elevated blood pressure compare to before.  Must not be anything because my doctors have not noticed.  I have gained 22 pounds.  Tried everything to lose the weight in a healthy way.  Eating 1,000 calories a day, working out 5 days a week.  Lots of cardio and weight training.  Has anyone had success? Funny thing is I didnt start gaining the first year.  Kimarie
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen side effects

Posts.Content: I was 46 when I had breast cancer, had lumpectomy, chemo and radiation.  I think I was just a scared as you.  The chemo was not as bad as having the flu.  Never got sick to my stomach.  The radiation made me tired.  But I am 48 and working full time and play golf every weekend.  I am always scared that cancer could come back, but I did everything available to keep it away.  I took tamoxifin for a year, and 2 months of femara.  I developed such strong depression, I am taking some time off from medication.  Will try it again, in a couple of months.  Good Luck with your decision. Kimarie
Posts.Title: chemo or no chemo?

Posts.Content: Dear Victoria,  I read your message with such a familiarity.  I had breast cancer with one node involved estrogen positive.  Had the lumpectomy, chemo, radiation and am on the tamoxifin now.  I am 48, was diagnosed at 46.  Chemo put me into menapause.  I took the tamoxifin for one year, but they told me I needed to try femara, since I was post menapause.  I lasted 2 months.  The emotional side effects and pain in my feet were unbearable for me.  My doctor never confirmed that the femara caused any of this.  I have a new oncologist.  She is working with me closely.  My emotional state is so out of wack.  Seems every 3 or 4 weeks I start having extreme anxiety attacks.  I have been back on tamoxifin for four months.  I have a prescription for valium.  So when I feel like I am losing my mind I can stop it from getting to bad.  My doctor said that if you took a antidepressant or anxiety medication while taking tamoxifin or Aromasin it would interfere with the treatment of squashing estrogen in your body.  I recently started reading the book "What your doctor May Not have told you about breast cancer".  Its scary.  Everything is scary.  I continually ask God to keep me close, I want to survive emotionally, and stay cancer free.  God bless all of us.     Kimarie  ps   I have gained 20lbs in the last year.  I hate my body.  I was a size 4 or 6, now I am a 10.  That is very vain, but that is who I am.
Posts.Title: More on personal side effects from Aromasin

Posts.Content: I am probably making a mistake but I quit taking femara last night.  I am going back on tamoxifin.  But if I dont start feeling like my old self, I will probably quit that too.  I want to feel normal again.  I want to lose this added weight.  I dont like feeling depressed and angry and on the edge.  I just want to go back to a normal life. Kimarie
Posts.Title: I have decided to Quit Drugs

Posts.Content: It has been two weeks.  I have felt alot better.  I am going to a funeral today and it makes me sad.  But I feel a normal sadness.  I have been making a point to laugh with my husband.  I am not sure why but I feel better.  I dont hate myself as much.  I dont seem to be so angry anymore.  I am not crying all the time.  I wish I could do the treatment and feel normal.  I dont want to take an antidepressant because they can make you gain more weight.  I would be sad if i got any heavier.  Catch twenty two.  Good Luck to us.
Posts.Title: Aromasin after five years?

Posts.Content: On 3/2/2007 Suzq53 wrote: Hi... Congratulations on being four years out! I can totally relate to the lower back pain you are having. I had serious back pain during radiation, related to a pinched nerve and sciatica (spelling?). My lower back has hurt almost constantly ever since. I so want the pain to go away. I know it will take time for the aromosin to get totally out of my system. On March 5th, I will have been off it for two weeks. I have to say that I already notice some differences in how I feel. More energy, less emotional. It might be pychological, because I wanted to "be better" so badly...but I'll take it! I'm 54 years old -- so we are near the same age. I, too, don't believe that these aches are age related. Also, I had terrible hot flashes from the time of chemo, and they didn't go away until this last year. I know that chemo put me into menopause, and that resulted in the hot flashes -- but, for sure, the Tamoxifin and the Aromosin had an effect too. Best wishes to you and thank you for posting your message. I'm sorry you have the pains -- but it is reassuring to me that possibly the pain is drug related and there is hope that it will subside. Dear Suz,  You are saying everything I am thinking and feeling.  I am 48 and so tired of hearing I am just getting older.  Wrist pains, feet hurt, especially when I get out of bed.  Been off femara for about 3 1/2 weeks.  Took Tamoxifin for 1 year.  I have gained 18 pounds.  My face looks swollen all the time.  I just would like to feel normal again.  Like two years ago when I started treatment.  I will say that I am a little better.  Not crying as much.  My husband is trying so hard to make me feel loved and to make me laugh by being goofy.  God gave me a super husband.  I am so thankful.  He is going with me to my next oncology appt.  I figure I need an advocate, because I am sure they will try to bully me into taking some form of the medication.  But I need a break for now.  Maybe will feel like taking at another time in my life.  May God Bless us and keep us cancer free.   Kimarie
Posts.Title: Aromasin after five years?

Posts.Content: I read your message, I have felt some of the same things you described.  I only took tamoxifin for 1 year, femara for 2 months.  My sadness started after I started the femara, they said he had nothing to do with my moods.  I quit taking everything.  I will probably regret this.  But I needed to feel normal for awhile.  Had all the same treatments you did.  Wish we knew for sure.  Good luck   Kimarie
Posts.Title: Aromasin after five years?

Posts.Content: Hello, first timer.  I am doing a clinical study for the drug Femara.  I am two years out since finding breast cancer.  Had partial masectomy, did 4 rounds chemo 6 1/2 weeks radiation, 1 year of tamoxifin.  Been on Femara for 6 weeks.  I am 47.  Chemo put me in menapause.  Question?  Some days I feel like strangleing somebody, some days I just cry.  Sometimes I am so mad, I hate myself.  I think my emotional roller coaster is going to drive me crazy.  Sound familiar, let me know.
Posts.Title: Femara for Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: On 1/29/2007 Wesdutchblade wrote: Hi, I'm 17, going to be 18 on sunday, and my surgery to have a mysterious lump removed is the next morning. I don't know what to expect, the lump is very painful, wich i know is not supposed to be cancer but on my ultrasound it showed a mass that looked half solid and half liquid. I really don't know what to think, the doctor says there is a small chance of it being cancer but that doesn't make me feel any better, the last time someone told me it wasn't something, it was. I knew I had appendicitis, they said I probably didn't, but I did, same with a fractured pelvis! and that was all last year! (not including a knee surgery last year as well) Can someone just help me with what I should expect of my surgery and maybe even the results, the lump has been there for nearly 3 months now and it is being completely removed next monday! thanks everyone!!! Dear 17, I know it is very scary.  I am 47 and had a lump removed almost two years ago.  As far as the pain, hardly any.  My surgeon did a nice job my breast looks pretty normal.  Very little scar.  My lump was about the size of a walnut.  I will be praying for you.     Kimarie
Posts.Title: Too young for this!

Posts.Content: On 1/29/2007 Nbhadia wrote:   On 1/29/2007 Kimarie wrote: Hello, first timer.  I am doing a clinical study for the drug Femara.  I am two years out since finding breast cancer.  Had partial masectomy, did 4 rounds chemo 6 1/2 weeks radiation, 1 year of tamoxifin.  Been on Femara for 6 weeks.  I am 47.  Chemo put me in menapause.  Question?  Some days I feel like strangleing somebody, some days I just cry.  Sometimes I am so mad, I hate myself.  I think my emotional roller coaster is going to drive me crazy.  Sound familiar, let me know. Hello Kimarie, I have been taking Femara almost 3 yrs. now. I had a reoccurence of breast cancer after 14 yrs.!  In 1989 I had BC & had a mastectomy, reconstruction & 6 mos. chemo. It also put me in menopause at 41 yrs. Then I didn't take any drugs after that and was ok for 14 yrs. until 2003. I found a small bump near my sternum & yes, it was BC again - a tumor near my implant and it had also spread to my sternum bone.  So I went thru 8 mos. of chemo & 6 wks. radiation. Then I started taking Femara (both times the BC was estrogen positive.)  I have many side effects from Femara: bone pain, joint pain, lower back pain, weight gain, and lots more wrinkles then ever, plus it made my cholesterol go up!  (I am now 59).   At first my oncologist was going to put me on it for 5 yrs. but now he said he's leaving me on it indefinitely since it's keeping the cancer away. I was surprised when he said that but then again, I do want to stay on it if it keeps me safe. Of course I know there are no guarantees with this disease but at least Femara is what we have now to help us.  As far as the side effects you are having now, all I can say is that they probably will subside as your body readjusts  to the drug. But also be prepared for new ones to pop up ... I also have been taking Fosamax to prevent osteoporosis (it's a once a week pill with no side effects) and trying to exercise more which helps with the stiffness I seem to have all the time. But overall, even tho the side effects aren't pleasant, I am still here !!!!!  I hope I have helped you a little bit. Do write back if you'd like.    HadiaDear Hadia, Thank you for sharing info.  I quit smoking and started walking and jogging at the same time I started Femara.  I guess with so many different things popping up at one time, didnt know what caused what.  My feet are sore when I first get up.  My wrist and one thumb.  My back is also stiff.  Had adverse reaction from calcium supplement,quit taking that.  A large tendon in my arm has popped up to the surface, and is somewhat sore.  I should be thankfull that my cancer was treatable.  Guess emotionally I will stable out.  Or maybe start taking something to make me feel less stress.  I have also put on 8 lbs.  I have dieted my whole life, and now I cant lose any weight.  I am just maintaining my weight.  Kimarie
Posts.Title: Femara for Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Dear Kim,  I had my head shaved about 3 weeks after first chemo.  Yes I cried alot.  Grieving for my hair.  Very hard on a woman.  My daughter and best friend went to hair dressers with me.  I bought some head caps and some really pretty bandana's to wear.  The wigs I got itched something awful.  You sound like a caring daughter.  You can help by just pitching in with housework, shopping or cooking.  Your mom will get her hair back about two months after last chemo.   Kimarie
Posts.Title: supporting my mom

Posts.Content: Dear Newly diagnosed & scared. I had lumpectomy and one node removed.  Did 4 rounds of chemo and 61/2 weeks of radiation.  I was surprised how easy the chemo was.  I would finish chemo, go to grocery store and go home and cook dinner.  The medication they give you to keep you from getting sick is great.  Good luck and I can answer any questions you have.  Kimarie
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed and scared

Posts.Content: On 3/11/2007 Nativemainer wrote: Dear Kimarie How long did the 6 rounds of chemo take?  Where you able to work full time or part time?  I live alone and need to work at least 32 hours a week in a fairly strenous job to pay the mortgage and other bills.  Where you tired?  Where you able to drive yourself to your treatments?  If I am too sck to work or unable to drive I will have to go to a nursing home, and I'm only 48, I don't want to have to do that.  Sorry for all the questions, but I need to get good information--the doctors told my father he would nto be sick and would be able to continue to be as active as he was before, but he was so sick several days after each treatment that he couldn't even get out of bed, so I don't trust what the doctors say.  NativeMainer Dear Native Mainer,  I was 46 when I started chemo.  I drove myself.  You may feel a little tired from the drugs they give you to prevent you from getting sick.  For 3 days afterward I would take a prescription drug to ward off any stomach upset.  During my second chemo treatment, my white cells did go low, which made me feel like I had the flu in my body.  They gave me a shot to boost my white cells, which did make my legs and back cramp for a couple of days.  I was not working, but I played golf thru out my entire treatment.  Also bowled.  I was a lady of luxury.  Not any more now, I work 40 hrs a week.  The chemo just wasnt too bad for me.  Hope this helps.  Kimarie
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed and scared

Posts.Content: Hi, I had breast cancer, estrogen receptive, also spread to one lymp node.  Did the lumpectomy, chemo, radiation, one year tomaxifin, 2 months femara.  I quit taking everything.  Need a break.  My feet get very stiff.  When I wake in the morning, or set for awhile.  I have tenderness in my knees and wrist.  I have gotten very clutsy.  I am constantly droping things from my hand.  Not sure what caused all of this, but decided to stop treatment and take my chances for awhile.  All my scans recently said I was cancer free. I am 47, chemo put me into menapause, that might have something to do with it.  Not sure.  Kimarie
Posts.Title: Body pains

Posts.Content: Has anyone given any thought, that all the treatment we have been thru for breast cancer, chemo, radiation, and tamoxifin in my case.  Has caused an imbalance in our thryroid which may be the reason for our weight gain and foggy brains.  I recently called a wellness center that could not treat me for my menapause because of the estrogen positive cancer, which I knew.  But they mentioned how I should have my thyroid checked.  Tell me what you think. Kimarie
Posts.Title: Tamoxifin/Thyroid

Posts.Content: Dear Anita, I am two year survivor of breast cancer, had lumpectomy, chemo and radiation.  A couple of months after my radiation, I took a job as a daycare  teacher at a Montessorri School.  I took care of 2 to 3 year olds.  My husband thought I was crazy.  I had so much fun with those kids.  In the year I took care of them they gave me so much love.  My heart was so full.  After a year on the tamoxifin, I started getting very depressed and gained about 18 pounds.  I was always very slim and now I have a big stomach.  I have been off the meds for two months.  My depression went away, my weight stayed the same.  I am working full time as an Office Manager for my Dads company.  He needed me.  But I suggest you try something totally out of character.  See if you can find some fun.   Spread your Wings,  Kimarie
Posts.Title: going back to work

Posts.Content: I quit smoking last Thanksgiving.  Had been smoking 30 years.  I am proud of myself.  I took femara after the tamoxifin, for 2 months.  My doctors wanted me to take something because my cancer was estrogen receptive.  I needed some time off of the meds to get my mind right.  I dont like my heavy body, but your right we are vain, and that is that.  I am 48 and all of a sudden I feel old.  Two years ago when I found the cancer I was vibrant, looked great and felt great.  I dont understand what all the treatment of chemo, radiation and meds has done to my body.  I know it may save my life, but if I am going to live awhile, I want to feel good and look good.  My mind is better.  I am walking 2 to 3 miles a day.  Eating fairly healthy.  I have a sweet tooth. Kimarie
Posts.Title: going back to work

Posts.Content: Dear Barbara, the first year after my breast cancer treatment, I did not gain at all, if anything I was the smallest I had ever been.  Boom, year two was a whole different ball game.  Gained twenty pounds.  I have been exercising and dieting to stop the weight gain.  Which I have.  I haven't gained any for 4 months.  But I am watching everything I put in my mouth.  Maybe the medicine has alot to do with it.  I am taking tamoxifin, been on it for almost two years.  I am 48, chemo enduced menapause. Kimarie
Posts.Title: Weight Gain

Posts.Content: Theresa Marie, thank you for your message.  I called two different wellness centers in Houston that specialize in menapause and hormone imbalance.  They both refuse to treat me until I was two years passed taking the tamoxifin.  With Estrogen receptive cancer you are kinda at a loss for help with all the side affects.  My Oncologist told me her number one job was to keep my cancer from coming back. She cares how I feel but says she is helpless for any treatment of the hormone imbalance.  I tried taking femara and had extreme side affects.  I am tolerating the tamoxifin.  But my emotional problems are a battle.  Anger, depression, anxiety and foggy brain.  I am coming to terms with the fact this too shall pass.  Please let this time fly by. Kimarie
Posts.Title: Weight Gain

Posts.Content: On 2/21/2008 karen30 wrote: my doctor asked me if anyone in my family has ever had breast cancer and I said yes my grandmother on my fathers side and they said it didn't matter on the fathers side. Then i was told that wasn't true! Does anyone know? Hey Karen, My dad's mom had breast cancer, My Mom had breast cancer, and at 46 I was diagnosed with breast cancer.  Not sure how to answer your question. Kimarie Kimarie
Posts.Title: question about breast cancer

Posts.Content: I read your words, and it reminded me how I felt.  About 2 years after radiation and chemo I was taking femara.  Maybe 6 weeks and I felt like my whole life was in a black hole.  I was in so much mental pain, I started hitting myself to transfer the pain to physical.  I blamed it on medicine and quit taking everything for about 5 months.  I was slowly coming out of my depression.  I still to this day am not quite sure what caused my melt down.  That was a year ago.  I am much better now. I am on tamoxifin.  I have a year and half to go before my 5 years. God be with you, Kimarie
Posts.Title: Delayed emotional reaction to treatment

Posts.Content: On 10/23/2007 kdmackey wrote: I have went through a long drawn out period of my life.  Two mouths to be exact.  That doesn't sound like a long time but it is when you find two lumps in your breast and you first see a doctor then you go for a Mammagram.  Then you have to wait for the results on that .  Then the doctor sends you to have a ultrasound and they do this on the wrong breast.  You go to the doctor again and he sends you back to do a ultra sound on the right breast.  Then you go back to the doctor to get the result on this breast. They tell me they found somthing that didn't look right so they need to do a biopsy.  They did this while I was awake which was very scary.  I had to wait a week, well I called the doctor to find out if the results was in and the nurse said "no one has called you to make an app. to come in, can you come in today at 3:30." I didn't have time to call my daughter, she lived 2hrs away and I couldn't get ahold of my boyfriend so I had to go by myself.  I was along when the doctor told me I had breast cancer.  I'm scared, I know theres a lot of women who have and are going through the same thing I am.  Just need to talk to someone and hear there story and experiences.  I think there should be faster ways to get things done so you don't have to wait so long to find out your results. 10-23-07 has changed my life.   Dear KDMackey, I am so sorry you were alone, and that they drug there feet on telling you your results.  I think this happens to many people.  My breast cancer was a tumor size of walnut.  Estrogen positive and one lymp node affected.  I had chemo, radiation and I take tamoxifin now.  I am 48, was diagnosed at 46.  I am happy to answer any questions that I can.  Everyone responds differently.  So I can just reflect my own experience.  Kimarie
Posts.Title: today changed my life
